instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: Glass- or ITO-coated glass substrates with a vacuum-deposited titanium layer (99.9%) were used. For TMS preparation, the Ti-glass substrates were ultrasonically treated in 5 M NaOH (Sigma–Aldrich) at 80%-intensity with an UIP1000hd (Hielscher Ultrasonics) operated at 20 kHz with a maximal output power of 1 000 W. Samples were placed into teflon home-made holder at 1 cm distance perpendicular to sonotrode. For TNT preparation, the Ti–ITO–glass samples were anodized in an aqueous solution of ethylene glycol (2 vol % water) containing 0.75 wt% NH4F. At beginning of the anodizing, potential linearly increased from 0 to 40 V, than the anodizing performed at potentiostatic (40 V) mode till the total oxidation of a titanium layer on ITO. All samples were washed in ethanol and water. After washing, the structures were annealed at 450 °C in air. Milli-Q water was used in all aqueous solutions.

input: The synthesis involved growing a shell of silica in the presence of properly derivatized nanocrystals (NCs) onto preformed silica microspheres. instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: Mesoporous TiO2 beads were prepared through a combined sol-gel and solvothermal process. Titanium(IV) isopropoxide (TTIP) was used as the precursor, with ethanol and acetonitrile as solvents, and methylamine as a catalyst. The solvothermal treatment was carried out at 240°C for 6 hours, followed by calcination at 500°C for 2 hours. The morphology of the samples was observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The specific surface area and pore size distribution were measured using nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. The TiO2 beads were used to fabricate dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), and their photovoltaic performance was evaluated using current-voltage measurements and incident photon-to-current efficiency (IPCE) spectra.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: In a typical synthesis of CTOCs, the titanium precursor [Ti(OBu)4, 0.5 mmol] and monocarboxylic acid (1.05 mmol) were mixed in 2 mL ethylene glycol for 5 min to give a turbid solution. The mixture was then sealed in a pressure glass vessel and heated at 100˚C for 24 h. The as-formed colorless crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed by anhydrous THF for three times, and then dried at room temperature under vacuum. The synthesis of CTOCs in this work can be easily scaled up to gram scale. For convenience, CTOCs prepared with the use of propionic acid, methacrylic acid, and pivalic acid as the monocarboxylic acid were denoted as CTOC-1, CTOC-2, and CTOC-3, respectively.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: The TiO2 sphere coating suspension was prepared by adding measured amount of TiO2 spheres, ethyl cellulose, and sodium dodecyl sulfate into ethanol. The prepared samples were labeled as TA-01, TA-05, and TA-10 for the coating solution concentration of 1, 5, and 10 wt% TiO2, respectively. The solution was stirred at room temperature for 24 h and ultrasonicated for 30 min prior to the coating process. The alumina discs were pretreated with ethanol, acetic acid, and distilled water under ultrasonication for 10 min, respectively. In order to coat the TiO2 spheres firmly on the alumina disc, the alumina discs were dip-coated into TiO2 suspension for 10 s, followed by drying at 80 °C for 2 h. Finally, the coated alumina discs were calcined in the box furnace at 500 °C for 30 min with a heating rate of 1 °C/min.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: The MTR reactor consists of a cylindrical vessel (diameter 0.056m) containing 54 hollow quartz glass tubes (diameter 0.006m) coated on their peripheral surface with catalyst. The tubes were held securely within the reactor by two Teflon end plates, in which 54 holes were drilled. The reactor resembles that of a shell-and-tube heat exchanger with reaction liquid flowing through the shell-side and over the outside surfaces of the coated tubes, while light travels through the inside of the hollow tubes. One end of each tube was closed to prevent any reaction liquid entering the inside of the tubes, and they were also coated with aluminum for better utilization of axially exiting light.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: The samples to be tested were all prepared by the sol-gel technique. A 0.2M HNO3 solution was added dropwise at room temperature into a mixture of butyl titanate and isopropyl alcohol, and stirred with a magnetic stirrer, a yellow transparent gelation of butyl titanate was obtained. The molar ratio (C4H9O)4Ti : H2O : C3H8O was 15 : 40 : 10. After gelation was completed, the stable reagent (i.e., polyethylene alcohol) was added, it was then aged for 5 hours at room temperature and, subsequently, heated at 80°C for 12 hours and at 120°C for 24 hours in an oven to remove the alcohol. Finally, the solids were divided into four parts and sintered at 340°C, 440°C, 540°C, and 640°C for 30 minutes in a muffle furnace. The samples were cooled to room temperature, then crushed and sieved. Particles of about 1 mm were selected and used in the characterization of the pore structure of the solids.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: The red mud slurry with approximately 500 g/L or 39 wt.% solids content was collected from the last washer underflow outlet of the QAL mud washing circuit. The mud was diluted with water to 25 wt.% solids and thoroughly mixed and passed through a 600 µm sieve to remove any large fragments of scale and mud that could block the hydrocyclone. The sieved slurry was processed through the Mozley C700 hydrocyclone test rig using the C124 hydrocyclone (50 mm) with an 8 mm vortex finder under conditions that gave a nominal 5 µm, d50 size distribution. The pressure to the cyclone was maintained at just below 350 kPa to give the recommended cone-shaped spray issuing from the vortex at the bottom.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: The polymers utilized, four hydroxyl-terminated PDMS samples having quoted number-average molecular weights corresponding to M_n = 4.2, 18.0, 26.0, and 43.6 kg/mol, respectively, were obtained from the Huls America Company. Actual values of the weight-average molecular weight M_w, M_n, and polydispersity index M_w/M_n were determined using a Waters 746 gel permeation chromatography (GPC) instrument. TEOS was supplied by the Petrach Systems Company, and stannous octoate was obtained from the Pfaltz and Bauer Company. All other chemicals, including titanium n-butoxide, aluminum tri-sec-butoxide, zirconia n-propoxide, hydrochloric acid (HCl), ethanol, propanol, and isopropanol, were obtained from the Aldrich Company. Two fumed silica samples having primary particle sizes of 4 and 7 nm were supplied by the Degussa Corporation. A sequential two-step sol-gel approach was used to prepare these filled PDMS networks. In this technique, an unfilled PDMS network was first prepared by the usual end-linking reaction. The next step involved the swelling of the networks in a solution containing solvent and the ceramic precursors. These starting solutions were prepared by reacting TEOS and the other desired metal alkoxide. For in situ generating the silica-titania mixed oxide, titanium butoxide was introduced into the partially hydrolyzed TEOS solution with vigorous stirring at the chosen ratio of TEOS to titanium butoxide. For in situ generating silica-zirconia mixed oxides, zirconium propoxide was used instead of titanium butoxide, with 1-propanol as solvent. Finally, the starting solution for in situ-generating silica-alumina mixed oxide employed aluminum tri-sec-butoxide, and the solvent was isopropanol.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: A series of batch (bottle) emulsion copolymerizations of styrene and VIMZ were carried out using V-50 as a cationic initiator in a stirred reactor at 70°C for 18 h to develop a recipe that may be used to prepare uniform latex particles by using emulsifier-free emulsion copolymerization. The emulsion copolymerizations of St and VIMZ were also carried out in the presence of emulsifier. For this purpose, all ingredients are added into a 200-mL bottle and then the bottle was purged with nitrogen for 1 min. Right after this, the bottle prepared was capped and then tumbled at 70°C and a speed of 30 rpm for 18 h. Samples C03-12 and C05-06 exhibited a narrow particle size distribution. Samples C03-12 and C05-06 were repeated to prepare the seed particles on a large scale (i.e., R03-12 and R05-06, respectively) to study the imidazole-functionalized shell growth reaction. Several modes of monomer addition (without using any additional surfactants in the second-stage reaction) were explored to determine the conditions necessary for the effective incorporation of the imidazole groups onto the surface of seed particles. The solids content of the seed particles, R03-12, was 9.74 wt %. The number–average diameter (D_n) was 150 nm as measured by TEM, and the coefficient of variation in the number–average diameter was 8.9%. For V150-A, the seed latex particles were swollen with 1.0 g of styrene monomer in a tumbler at 25°C and a speed of 30 rpm for 24 h and the initiator solution (0.0245 g of V50 and 9.0 g of water) was subsequently added. In the case of V150-B, 0.4 g of VIMZ was added into the styrene-swollen seed latex particles before the polymerization was initiated. In the case of V150-C, all of the second-stage monomers were added just before the second-stage polymerization process was begun. Finally, V150-D used the seed particles swollen with all of the second-stage monomers. The second-stage polymerizations were carried out at 70°C for 20 h using the bottle polymerization process.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: Synthesis of surface-modified TiO2 nanoparticles: Cosolvent of ethanol (600 mL) and distilled water (400 mL) were put into a three-necked round bottom flask fitted with a reflux condenser. Exactly 7.5 mL of titanium oxychloride (Ti41 22 mol) dissolved in 35 mL of distilled water was added dropwise to the reactor. The mixed solution was stirred under nitrogen flow at 60°C and it turned cloudy after ≈ 3 h. The precipitated solid was isolated as wet cake by centrifugation at 5000 rpm and it was washed five times with ethylacetate. After a small part of this solid was dried in evacuated desiccators, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis of bare TiO2 was performed. Preparation of TiO2 nanoparticles modified by propionic acid: In a typical preparation, isolated wet cake of a precipitated solid, without drying, was directly added in excess amount of propionic acid (50 mL). After stirring as slurry for 24 h at room temperature, the precipitate formed was collected as wet cake by centrifugation and washed five times with ethylacetate to remove the extra propionic acid. The wet cake of TiO2 nanoparticles modified by propionic acid, without drying, was added to 50 g of cosolvent of n-butanol and toluene with a weight ratio of 1 : 1. In addition, it was sonicated for 1 h. The precipitated solid was perfectly dispersed into cosolvent of n-butanol and toluene. A colloidal solution of TiO2 nanoparticles modified by propionic acid was obtained. Preparation of TiO2 nanoparticles modified by propionic acid and a variety of alkyl amines: Excess amount of each alkyl amine (10 mL): (i) not addition (as the comparison), (ii) n-propylamine, (iii) n-hexylamine, (iv) n-dodecylamine were added to each separately prepared colloidal solution (cosolvent of n-butanol and toluene) of TiO2 nanoparticles modified by propionic acid. After stirring for 1 h, precipitated solids were obtained as wet cake by centrifugation and they were washed five times with ethylacetate to remove the extra amine. Each wet cake were added little by little to solvents as follows, (a) water, (b) 2-propanol, (c) chloroform, (d) toluene, and (e) THF, and they were sonicated for 1 h, and dispersibility was observed. Every dispersive property is summarized in Table I. The dispersibility of modified TiO2 changed according to the length of an alkyl chain of each amine.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: PFD was prepared by free radical copolymerization of VBDC (0.93 g, 3.51 mmol) and MMA (3 mL, 28 mmol) in the presence of MPMS (0.1 mL) as chain transfer agent initiated by V-70 (0.7 wt % for total monomer) in THF (42 mL) at 30°C for 24 h in a dark room. After polymerization, the copolymer was precipitated with a large excess of methanol. The yield of copolymer was 41% from gravimetric measurement. The content of DC groups of PFD was determined from the integration ratio of the methoxy protons (δ = 3.59 ppm) of MMA units to methylene protons (4.04 ppm) of the DC groups by a proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H-NMR) spectra. 1H-NMR spectroscopy (300 MHz, Bruker GPX300 NMR spectrometer, Germany) for PFD was performed in CDCl3. Synthesis of SiO2 hybrid nanoparticles modified with PFD (H-SiO2): SiO2 particles with average diameter of 192 nm were used in this study. For the surface modification, SiO2 particles were dispersed in THF (50 mL) and then PFD (0.5 g) was added to the dispersion. The mixture was stirred at 60°C for 24 h. After the reaction, the modified SiO2 particles were collected by centrifugation and washed with THF several times to remove unreacted PFD. The modified SiO2 particles were then dried under vacuum at 60°C for 24 h.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: Nafion solution (DE-520, EW1100) was purchased from DuPont Ind., which contains 5 wt % of perfluorosulfonate resin (H+ form) and 95 wt % of isopropanol/water mixture (10 : 9 weight ratios). Tetrabutyl titanate was received from Shanghai Reagent (China). Water was deionized through a Milli-Q system (Barnsted Nanopore, resistivity = 18.0 mΩ cm−1). N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) was dried over CaH2 and distilled under vacuum. All the other solvents and chemicals were reagent grade and were used as received. The referenced titania particles for zeta potential measurements were formed by hydrolysis of tetrabutyl titanate precursors in NMP/water solution at different pH values. Commercial Nafion solutions were evaporated at 120°C and redissolved in NMP. The desired quantity of precursor solutions was added dropwise to the Nafion solution under vigorous stirring in an inert nitrogen atmosphere at 120°C and allowed to cool down to 40°C. After adjusting the pH of the dispersion to ≈ 2.0 using 2M HCl solution, the mixture was continuously stirred for 8 h at 40°C and a clear sol containing hybrid Nafion-titania nanoparticles was obtained. Unless otherwise stated, the final concentration of Nafion is about 2 wt % based on our previous results. Hybrid membranes were prepared using a recasting process: the hybrid sol was first placed in a Petri dish, followed by the solvent evaporation at 100°C under vacuum for 8 h and then posttreated at 150°C for 3 h. The formed membranes were than cleaned using a standard procedure at 80°C for 30 min in 5% H2O2 solution, in deionized water, in 0.5M H2SO4 solution, and finally in deionized water again.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: PP and EVOH nanofibers were prepared according to a previously published procedure. EVOH was dried in an electric heating air-blowing drier for 24 h at 80°C, and the other materials were dried in a vacuum drying oven for 24 h at 100°C before melt blending. PP/CAB and EVOH/CAB blends with the weight ratios of 20/80 were fed into the co-rotating twin-screw extruder with a screw speed of 50 rpm and melting zone temperature of 200–225°C for EVOH/CAB and 190–230°C for PP/CAB. The blends were extruded by a take-up device and water-cooled to room temperature. Then, the extrudants were immersed in acetone via a Soxhlet extractor at room temperature for 24 h to remove CAB from the blends. After removing the matrix phase CAB, PP and EVOH nanofibers were obtained for the following preparation of P/E-NCM. The prepared PP and EVOH nanofibers were mixed with the weight ratios of 10/90, 20/80, 30/70, 40/60, dispersed using a mechanical disintegrator for 30 s to obtain a consistent fiber suspension, and then a layer of the fibers was deposited onto a supporting PP nonwoven mat. After drying in an electric heating air-blowing drier for 5 min at 60°C, the P/E-NCM with a controlled thickness was released from the supporting PP nonwoven mat. The heat-treated P/E-NCM was prepared by drying in a vacuum drying oven for 10 min at 150°C.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: The nanofillers were first dried in an oven at 100°C for 2 h and added to the polyol. The mixture was then sonicated using a Cole Parmer CP750 ultrasonic homogenizer for 2 min to obtain a homogeneously dispersed suspension. For each nanofiller, rigid polyurethane foams were prepared at concentrations of 1 and 10 wt% in polyol. Nanofilled rigid polyurethane foams were prepared using a three-step procedure. The first step involved the dispersion of the nanofillers in the polyol, followed by the addition of cyclopentane, which was stirred at 2000 rpm for 30 s using a mechanical stirrer. Finally, the isocyanate was added to the mixture, which was additionally mixed for 5 s. The mixture was then poured into an open rectangular aluminum mold and allowed to cure for 24 h.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: The ultrafine particles were created by using a novel and patented technique. The base polymer powders were prepared as either Epoxy pure or epoxy/polyester Hybrid formulations, which were either with or without micron-sized TiO2. All of the formulations were enriched with TiO2 nanoparticles (0.5% w/w) as a flow additive to improve flowability and CaO (5.0% w/w) as a bioactive agent to enhance biocompatibility. These powder mixtures were thoroughly mixed in a high-shear mixer and passed through a sieve (35 mm). The ultrafine powder formulations were used to create dry powder coatings on titanium surfaces by using a well-proven technique. The ultrafine particles were charged (20 kV) and sprayed with a Corona Gun, so that they were electrostatically attracted to grounded titanium surfaces. The dry powder-coated disks were then cured (200°C, 10 min) in a high-performance air flow oven.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: For the preparation of Alg/TiO2 beads, TiO2 nanoparticles were first suspended in ultra-pure water at a concentration of 50 g/L and were followed by dissolving sodium alginate powder in the TiO2 suspension at a concentration of 30 g/L. Subsequently, 25 mL of the prepared Alg/TiO2 solution was extruded through an 18-gauge needle at a flow rate of 1 mL/min into a beaker containing 400 mL of CaCl2 solution (20 g/L) as the gelation bath to form the Alg/TiO2 beads. Blank alginate beads (Alg) without TiO2 were prepared to serve as control in this study. The blank Alg beads were prepared under similar process conditions with the exception that TiO2 nanoparticles were not added to the sodium alginate solution. The as-prepared blank Alg beads or Alg/TiO2 beads were rinsed with 400 mL of ultra-pure water trice to remove the residual calcium ions.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: We report a novel, green hydrothermal-synthesis route to well-dispersed anatase TiO2 nanoparticles with particle sizes of 9–16 nm in the presence of b-CD (b-cyclodextrin). During the synthesis process, the CD-containing synthesis mixture assembled in both longitudinal and latitudinal directions. Driven by the interaction between molecules, the b-CDs assembled in the longitudinal direction to form long-chain compounds, whereas in the latitudinal direction, they tended to form regular aggregates through coordination with the Ti species from the hydrolysis of tetrabutyl titanate. The low b-CD dosage and the high product yield (> 90%) demonstrated well the potential of this synthesis route in the large-scale industrial production of anatase nanoparticles.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: Materials: Titanium(IV) isopropoxide (TTiP, 97%, Aldrich, USA), β-CD (Tokyo Kasei Kogyo Co., Ltd, Japan), and sulfuric acid (98%; Daejung Chemicals & Metals, South Korea) were used without further purification. 2,4-Pentanedione (ACAC, ≥99%; Aldrich, USA) was used as a retarding agent to control the hydrolysis of TTiP. Preparation of Mesoporous TiO2: The mesoporous TiO2 was synthesized as follows. 3 g of β-CD were dissolved in 200 mL of acidic water (pH 1.5). 2.25, 4.05, and 6.75 g of TTiP (mol ratio of β-CD:TTiP = 1:3, 1:6, 1:9, respectively) were then individually mixed with ACAC in a mole ratio of 1:1. TTiP–ACAC mixtures were individually added dropwise to acidic β-CD solution and were vigorously stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After 24 h, light yellow powders were hydrothermally treated at 90 °C for 3 h. The solids were filtered out and were washed several times with water and ethanol to remove the β-CD and the ACAC. The samples were then dried in a vacuum at room temperature, and the resulting materials are denoted as CD–Ti (1:3), CD–Ti (1:6), and CD–Ti (1:9), corresponding to the mol ratio between β-CD and TTiP. We also prepared Ti-3 as a counterpart of CD–Ti (1:3). Ti-3 was prepared in the same manner as that used to produce CD–Ti (1:3), with the exception of the absence of β-CD.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: Mesoporous C and N codoped anatase nanocrystal–carbon composites were synthesized by chelation-assisted co-assembly of urea, TiCl4, resols, and triblock copolymer. The composite catalysts have biphasic constituents in the pore walls of amorphous carbon and C,N-codoped anatase nanoparticles (≈ 4.0 nm) that are “glued” together. The composite catalysts also have open mesopores with high surface areas (≈ 340 m² g⁻¹), large pore volumes (≈ 0.20 cm³ g⁻¹), and uniform pore sizes (≈ 5.0 nm). Upon calcination in air at 350 °C, the main-group-elements-codoped anatase nanoparticles with a size of 4.3 nm can be obtained. The C,N-codoped anatase nanoparticles feature a clear redshift absorption towards the visible-light region and exhibit remarkable degradation efficiency for phenol. A repeated accumulation–photodegradation process is adopted to remove high concentrations of phenol (100 mg L⁻¹) from water, thereby avoiding the use of organic solvent and the posttreatment of the catalyst. After six cycles, phenol is almost completely degraded.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: TiO2-supported Pd(z)Pt(1−z) catalysts were prepared by two methods: water-in-oil microemulsion (MicE) and incipient wetness impregnation (IWI). The MicE method involved the in situ reduction of metal precursors in a water-in-oil microemulsion, leading to the direct deposition of reduced nanoparticles onto the support. The IWI method involved impregnating the support with a metal precursor solution, followed by calcination and reduction under hydrogen flow. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, TEM, and XPS. The catalytic performance was evaluated for the green synthesis of methyl formate through methanol oxidation at 323 K and ambient pressure.

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: Gold nanoparticles were prepared by a modified deposition/precipitation method using urea and NaBH4 as a chemical reductant (DP-UC). TiO2 (Degussa P25) was dispersed in distilled water with urea, and NaAuCl4·2H2O solution was added. The mixture was stirred for 4 h at 353 K, filtered, and washed. The material was then suspended in distilled water, and a freshly prepared solution of NaBH4 was added under vigorous stirring at room temperature. The sample was filtered, washed, and dried at 373 K for 4 h. The actual Au loading was checked by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS). The catalysts were characterized by DRIFTS, XPS, TEM, and N2 physisorption. CO oxidation activity tests were carried out to evaluate the catalytic performance.

input: Ultrafine ruthenium nanocatalysts were prepared by a plasma-assisted synthesis at < 100 °C. The RuCl3 precursor was treated with cold plasma to decompose it into Ru nanoparticles, which were then loaded onto carbon and TiO2 supports. The resulting Ru nanoparticles were monodispersed (typical size 2 nm) and remained stable upon loading. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, XPS, TEM, and N2 adsorption measurements. The catalytic performance was evaluated for organosilane oxidation and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER).

instruction: extract the relevant data from the experimental text
input: Mesoporous titanium dioxide (TiO2) was synthesized by a sol-gel method using biosurfactant phosphatidylcholines (PC) as an organic template. Titanium tetrabutoxide (TBOT) was used as the precursor. PC was dissolved in acidified butanol, and TBOT was added dropwise with vigorous stirring. The solution was placed in a water bath at 60 °C for 3 h, followed by the addition of deionized water. The gelatin solution was aged overnight, dried, and calcined at different temperatures (450 °C, 600 °C, 700 °C, and 800 °C) in air for 2.5 h. The samples were characterized by TEM, BET, XRD, and UV-VIS spectroscopy.

input: The coating procedure involves preparing TiO2 coatings on glass beads in a pilot-plant scale fluidized-bed reactor. The glass beads (soda-lime glass, diameter: 750-1000 μm) were coated using a suspension of TiO2 (P25) in water (c = 30 g/L, suspension feed rate: 14 g/min) as the coating agent. In some experiments, methyl cellulose (10.5 g/L) was added to the coating suspension. The coated glass beads were then calcined at 623 K for 120 minutes. The thickness of the TiO2 layers was determined by preparing cross-section polishes of the coated beads and analyzing them using spatially-resolved Raman microscopy.

input: The synthesis of layered bimetallic gold-palladium colloids involves the seed-growth method. Gold seeds are covered by palladium layers of various thicknesses, and vice versa. The outer metal is coordinated by trisulfonated triphenylphosphine and sodium sulfanilate ligands to stabilize the bimetallic particles, allowing them to be isolated in the solid state and redispersed in water. The thickness of the metal 2 layer can be modified by controlling the molar amount of ionic metal 2 and the molar amount of metal 1 colloids.
